UI_visible_response: "Under the Dome" is a work of very broad, very black social satire, according to a review in Bookforum, where it was noted that the individual characters don't seem to matter very much1. It originally started as a novel by Stephen King published in 2009. The story revolves around a small town that becomes inexplicably sealed off from the rest of the world by an enormous transparent dome7. This narrative was adapted into an American science fiction drama television series which premiered on CBS on June 24, 20132, and aired until its cancellation after three seasons on September 10, 20155. The TV series has been described as broadcast television's most enjoyable science-fiction/fantasy series by Ken Tucker of Yahoo!3, though it also delves into exploring the dark side of humans in captivity through its sci-fi drama format6. More recently, "Under the Dome" has been seen as a microcosm of society, reflecting on how individuals and communities react during crises4.
traffic_visible_response: "Under the Dome" is a work of very broad, very black social satire, according to a review in Bookforum, where it was noted that the individual characters don't seem to matter very much [[1]]. It originally started as a novel by Stephen King published in 2009. The story revolves around a small town that becomes inexplicably sealed off from the rest of the world by an enormous transparent dome [[7]]. This narrative was adapted into an American science fiction drama television series which premiered on CBS on June 24, 2013 [[2]], and aired until its cancellation after three seasons on September 10, 2015 [[5]]. The TV series has been described as broadcast television's most enjoyable science-fiction/fantasy series by Ken Tucker of Yahoo! [[3]], though it also delves into exploring the dark side of humans in captivity through its sci-fi drama format [[6]]. More recently, "Under the Dome" has been seen as a microcosm of society, reflecting on how individuals and communities react during crises [[4]].
